original_title: Sri Lanka opted for some DDR to avoid further tax hikes: Minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka had opted for some domestic debt treatment as it was not possible to made sovereign debt sustainable without further tax hikes and spending cuts, State Minister for Finance Shehan Semasinghe said.
Sri Lanka’s rupee bond holders had taken a severe hit from inflation and depreciation of the currency and the stance of the authorities was to exclude them from re-structuring, he told parliament.
The International Monetary Fund had later done the debt analysis and target were set to make Sri Lanka’s debt sustainable again.

Under the DSA, the so-called gross financing needs or debt rollovers and new financing has to be below 8.5 percent of gross domestic product on average between 2027 and 2032. The ceilings cannot be met without at least a maturity extension of debt at projected GDP numbers or around 3.1 percent, according to analysts.
One choice was to impose more tax increases, cut spending and make more painful fiscal adjustments, Semasinghe told parliament in response to a question from opposition leader Sajith Premadasa.
Trying to reach debt sustainability only by improving the primary balance of the budget worsened the socio-economic cost, he said.
Instead, it was seen that a to minimize the socio-economic cost a mix of fiscal adjustments and some domestic debt ‘optimization’ was the correct approach, he said.
The government has already said that any Sri Lanka domestic debt treatment will be taken while ensuring financial stability, he said.
“To protect the stability of the financial system, all required step, at all required times, will be taken expeditiously,” Semasinghe said.
The parameters of domestic debt ‘optimization’ has not yet been decided, he said.
Sri Lanka’s overall debt restructuring strategy will be made known as soon as it is decided, Semasinghe said.
Sri Lanka authorities had said any restructuring will be voluntary and major bond holders will be approached.
The overall debt re-structuring strategy was originally expected by end April but has since been delayed till mid-May, the central bank’s Director of Economic Research P K G Harishchandra said.
Sri Lanka is one of several countries caught in default wave after several years monetary instability.(Colombo/April26/2023)
